title: 113_hr4756
content: The Act is titled the "Bullying Redress and Verified Enforcement Act" or the "BRAVE Act." It amends Title IX of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include reporting requirements on bullying. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying. A local educational agency must report bullying incidents within 7 business days, detailing the acts, any protected characteristics involved, and the response by agency employees. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying. An employee of a local educational agency who is informed of bullying by a student but the student requests non-reporting shall not be required to report. The agency must designate an individual to receive reports of bullying and inform all employees of the contact information. Within 60 days of receiving a report, the designated individual must inform all employees of the acts and response, excluding any student's identifiable information. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to include reporting requirements on bullying. A local educational agency must publish quarterly reports summarizing reported bullying incidents and responses, excluding any student's identifiable information. The reports also inform the public of the right to file a complaint. The "BRAVE Act" amends Title IX to require local educational agencies to publish quarterly reports on bullying incidents and responses, excluding student identifiable information. Agencies must annually review bullying policies and certify compliance with the Act to receive federal funding. The Office of Civil Rights handles complaints related to bullying. The BRAVE Act amends Title IX to mandate local educational agencies to report bullying incidents quarterly and review policies annually to receive federal funding. The Office of Civil Rights handles complaints regarding non-compliance with the Act, establishing a procedure for submitting complaints and investigating them. The BRAVE Act requires local educational agencies to report bullying incidents quarterly and review policies annually to receive federal funding. The Office of Civil Rights can take actions such as withholding funds, issuing complaints, or entering into compliance agreements with non-compliant agencies. Complaint information must be made public on the Department of Education's website within 60 days. The BRAVE Act mandates that the Department of Education website must provide information on bullying complaints, including details of protected characteristics if relevant, while excluding any personally identifiable information. Bullying is defined as severe, pervasive acts causing harm or concern for a student's well-being, leading them to withdraw from school activities. The BRAVE Act requires the Department of Education website to include information on bullying complaints related to protected characteristics such as race, color, sex, religion, national origin, disability, gender, gender identity, and sexual orientation, which may cause a student to withdraw from school activities.
